TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi beforefieldinit WorkflowQueue extends System.Object

Attribute.AttributeName: System.Obsolete("The System.Workflow.* types are deprecated. Instead, please use the new types from System.Activities.*")

remarks.format:
## Remarks
> [!NOTE] > [!INCLUDE[DeprecatedContent](~/includes/deprecatedcontent-md.md)]
Workflow queues are used to pass messages between a host or host services and activities in a workflow. Any activity can create a <xref:System.Workflow.Runtime.WorkflowQueue> by calling <xref:System.Workflow.Runtime.WorkflowQueuingService.CreateWorkflowQueue%2A?displayProperty=nameWithType>, and a host, a service, or another activity can call <xref:System.Workflow.Runtime.WorkflowQueue.Enqueue%2A> to add an item to that <xref:System.Workflow.Runtime.WorkflowQueue>. You can subscribe to the <xref:System.Workflow.Runtime.WorkflowQueue.QueueItemAvailable> event to be notified when an item arrives on the <xref:System.Workflow.Runtime.WorkflowQueue>. You can use <xref:System.Workflow.Runtime.WorkflowQueue.Peek%2A> to examine an item at the beginning of the <xref:System.Workflow.Runtime.WorkflowQueue> and <xref:System.Workflow.Runtime.WorkflowQueue.Dequeue%2A> to remove an item from the <xref:System.Workflow.Runtime.WorkflowQueue>. Each <xref:System.Workflow.Runtime.WorkflowQueue> is associated with a <xref:System.Workflow.Runtime.WorkflowQueuingService> that you can use to perform other management operations on the <xref:System.Workflow.Runtime.WorkflowQueue>, such as deleting the queue. <xref:System.Workflow.Runtime.WorkflowQueue.QueuingService%2A> exposes the <xref:System.Workflow.Runtime.WorkflowQueuingService> associated with this <xref:System.Workflow.Runtime.WorkflowQueue>.
## Examples The following code example demonstrates how you can create a <xref:System.Workflow.Runtime.WorkflowQueue> by calling the <xref:System.Workflow.Runtime.WorkflowQueuingService.GetWorkflowQueue%2A?displayProperty=nameWithType> method. It also uses the <xref:System.Workflow.Runtime.WorkflowQueue.Count%2A> property to determine whether any messages exist in the current queue. Finally, the code uses the <xref:System.Workflow.Runtime.WorkflowQueue.Dequeue%2A> method to remove and return the first object in the queue.
This code example is part of the File Watcher Activity SDK Sample from the FileSystemEvent.cs file. For more information, see [File System Watcher Activity](https://docs.microsoft.com/previous-versions/dotnet/netframework-3.5/ms741707(v=vs.90)).
[!code-csharp[WF_Samples#227](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_CFX/wf_samples/cs/snippets24.cs#227)] [!code-vb[WF_Samples#227](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_CFX/wf_samples/vb/snippets24.vb#227)]

Docs.summary: Gets the number of items contained in the .
Docs.value: The number of items in the workflow queue.

## Examples The following code example demonstrates how you can create a <xref:System.Workflow.Runtime.WorkflowQueue> by calling the <xref:System.Workflow.Runtime.WorkflowQueuingService.GetWorkflowQueue%2A?displayProperty=nameWithType> method. It also uses the <xref:System.Workflow.Runtime.WorkflowQueue.Count%2A> property to determine whether any messages exist in the current queue. Finally, the code uses the <xref:System.Workflow.Runtime.WorkflowQueue.Dequeue%2A> method to remove and return the first object in the queue.
This code example is part of the File Watcher Activity SDK Sample from the FileSystemEvent.cs file. For more information, see [File System Watcher Activity](https://docs.microsoft.com/previous-versions/dotnet/netframework-3.5/ms741707(v=vs.90)).

remarks.format:
## Remarks You can check <xref:System.Workflow.Runtime.WorkflowQueue.Count%2A> to determine whether the <xref:System.Workflow.Runtime.WorkflowQueue> is empty before you call <xref:System.Workflow.Runtime.WorkflowQueue.Dequeue%2A>, or you can catch the <xref:System.InvalidOperationException>.
## Examples The following code example demonstrates how you can create a <xref:System.Workflow.Runtime.WorkflowQueue> by calling the <xref:System.Workflow.Runtime.WorkflowQueuingService.GetWorkflowQueue%2A?displayProperty=nameWithType> method. It also uses the <xref:System.Workflow.Runtime.WorkflowQueue.Count%2A> property to determine whether any messages exist in the current queue. Finally, the code uses the <xref:System.Workflow.Runtime.WorkflowQueue.Dequeue%2A> method to remove and return the first object in the queue.
This code example is part of the File Watcher Activity SDK Sample from the FileSystemEvent.cs file. For more information, see [File System Watcher Activity](https://docs.microsoft.com/previous-versions/dotnet/netframework-3.5/ms741707(v=vs.90)).

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig instance void Enqueue(object item) cil managed

Docs.param: The object to add to the .
Docs.summary: Adds an object to the end of the .

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig instance object Peek() cil managed

Docs.summary: Returns the object at the beginning of the without removing it.
Docs.returns: The object at the beginning of the .

remarks.format: ## Remarks This method is similar to the <xref:System.Workflow.Runtime.WorkflowQueue.Dequeue%2A> method, but <xref:System.Workflow.Runtime.WorkflowQueue.Peek%2A> does not modify the <xref:System.Workflow.Runtime.WorkflowQueue>. You can check <xref:System.Workflow.Runtime.WorkflowQueue.Count%2A> to determine whether the <xref:System.Workflow.Runtime.WorkflowQueue> is empty before you call <xref:System.Workflow.Runtime.WorkflowQueue.Dequeue%2A>, or you can catch the <xref:System.InvalidOperationException>.

MemberSignature.Value: Public Custom Event QueueItemArrived As EventHandler(Of QueueEventArgs)

Docs.summary: Occurs when an item is delivered on this .

remarks.format: ## Remarks This event is only used for processing that must occur synchronously with event delivery to the workflow instance. The event handler may execute on a non-workflow thread so access to any shared workflow object, for example, any <xref:System.Workflow.ComponentModel.DependencyObject>, must be protected.

MemberSignature.Value: Public Custom Event QueueItemAvailable As EventHandler(Of QueueEventArgs)

Docs.summary: Occurs when an item is available on this .

remarks.format: ## Remarks The <xref:System.Workflow.Runtime.WorkflowQueue.QueueItemAvailable> event is raised in an asynchronous manner. The sender for the <xref:System.Workflow.Runtime.WorkflowQueue.QueueItemAvailable> event will be the <xref:System.Workflow.ComponentModel.ActivityExecutionContext> of the subscribing <xref:System.Workflow.ComponentModel.Activity>.

MemberSignature.Value: Public ReadOnly Property QueueName As IComparable
public: property IComparable ^ QueueName { IComparable ^ get(); };

Docs.summary: Gets the name of the workflow queue.

remarks.format: ## Remarks The name of the workflow queue is set by the <xref:System.Workflow.Runtime.WorkflowQueuingService.CreateWorkflowQueue%2A> method.

MemberSignature.Value: Public ReadOnly Property QueuingService As WorkflowQueuingService

Docs.summary: Gets the queuing service associated with this .
Docs.value: A that represents the queuing service associated with this .

Docs.param: A subscriber for that implements the interface.

Registers a subscriber to the event.

remarks.format: ## Remarks You can use the overloaded <xref:System.Workflow.Runtime.WorkflowQueue.RegisterForQueueItemAvailable%2A> methods to register a subscriber for the <xref:System.Workflow.Runtime.WorkflowQueue.QueueItemAvailable> event. The <xref:System.Workflow.Runtime.WorkflowQueue.QueueItemAvailable> event is used to notify subscribers that an item has been delivered (in an asynchronous manner) to this <xref:System.Workflow.Runtime.WorkflowQueue>.

remarks.format:
## Examples The following code example demonstrates how you can create a <xref:System.Workflow.Runtime.WorkflowQueue> by calling the <xref:System.Workflow.Runtime.WorkflowQueuingService.GetWorkflowQueue%2A?displayProperty=nameWithType> method. It also uses the <xref:System.Workflow.Runtime.WorkflowQueue.RegisterForQueueItemAvailable%2A> to register the specified listener.
This code example is part of the File Watcher Activity SDK Sample from the FileSystemEvent.cs file. For more information, see [File System Watcher Activity](https://docs.microsoft.com/previous-versions/dotnet/netframework-3.5/ms741707(v=vs.90)).

Docs.summary: Registers a subscriber to the event.

remarks.format: ## Remarks If the qualified name of the subscribing activity is supplied by `subscriberQualifiedName`, it is returned in <xref:System.Workflow.Runtime.WorkflowQueueInfo.SubscribedActivityNames%2A?displayProperty=nameWithType> of <xref:System.Workflow.Runtime.WorkflowQueueInfo> associated with this queue when <xref:System.Workflow.Runtime.WorkflowInstance.GetWorkflowQueueData%2A?displayProperty=nameWithType> is called.

## Examples The following code example demonstrates how you can create a <xref:System.Workflow.Runtime.WorkflowQueue> by calling the <xref:System.Workflow.Runtime.WorkflowQueuingService.GetWorkflowQueue%2A?displayProperty=nameWithType> method. It also uses the <xref:System.Workflow.Runtime.WorkflowQueue.UnregisterForQueueItemAvailable%2A> to unregister the specified listener.
This code example is part of the File Watcher Activity SDK Sample from the FileSystemEvent.cs file. For more information, see [File System Watcher Activity](https://docs.microsoft.com/previous-versions/dotnet/netframework-3.5/ms741707(v=vs.90)).
